title: 112_hr6422
content:
The Act may be cited as the "International Conservation Corps Act of 2012". Congress acknowledges the deficit in developing countries' ability to sustainably manage natural resources, leading to conflicts, corruption, and human rights abuses. Successful resource management in these countries can prevent conflict and benefit their development. The United States has a security interest in addressing these issues. The United States aims to share its expertise in natural resource management with developing countries to help them establish successful programs. Retiring professionals can volunteer to assist other countries in managing their resources sustainably. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of State, will establish a program to provide grants to nonprofit organizations for volunteers to assist foreign countries in managing their natural resources sustainably. This includes professional, scientific, and technical assistance for developing, managing, and protecting national parks, wildlife, and other protected areas. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, will identify and notify foreign countries for participation in the program, encouraging them to seek participation. Grants will be awarded to qualifying nonprofit organizations for volunteers to assist in managing natural resources in foreign countries. To be eligible for a grant, a nonprofit organization must submit an application to the Secretary with information on expertise, experience, and capacity. The application must be submitted in the required time, form, and manner. The Secretary will solicit applications from qualifying nonprofits and approve them promptly upon receipt. Upon receipt of an application, the Secretary shall approve or disapprove it. Once approved, a grant will be provided to the qualifying nonprofit organization promptly. SEC. 6. USE OF FUNDS.

Organizations receiving grants must use funds to recruit skilled volunteers for projects in foreign countries. Volunteers will work on appropriate projects in the program.

SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Organizations receiving grants must submit periodic reports to the Secretary for project evaluation and improvement. Reports will be made available to the public online. SEC. 8. TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF VOLUNTEER SERVICE. SEC. 8. TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF VOLUNTEER SERVICE. Volunteers in the program will be assigned to projects based on terms determined by the Secretary. They will receive a stipend to cover various costs. SEC. 9. FUNDING. $10,000,000 from unobligated funds for fiscal years 2013 through 2017 is authorized for this Act. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "program" refers to the program established under section 3, "qualifying nonprofit organization" refers to an entity described in section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior.
